body: This is a shortcoming and is the reason (maybe) why I need to check balances in the monitors.
Need a test case to prove that this either happens or does not happen. Fix it, obviously, if it does happen. Close it if it doesn't. I think this may be fixed.
Completed prior to first upload to quickBlocks.
This is mostly mitigated by the `walletlib` code since most times the incoming transactions (which is what this is referring to) are many times from wallets. Don't close this, but lower priority.
Cannot reproduce. Probably fixed when move to Toml files.
Fixed a long time ago.
This was fixed a long time ago.
Using #!/usr/bin/env bash works better and will find 'bash' where ever it is as long as it's in the user's $PATH.

Not really needed. Closing.
Duplicate of #15
This is already implemented prior to version 0.1.0
This is already implemented prior to version 0.1.0

On my new computer, I did not store 'ethabi' which is probably the cause of the bug where the ethslurp tests fail (i.e. do not properly parse the functions) the first time the data is slurped, but they do pass on subsequent runs. So we get new data in, which does not have a parsed function, and we add it to 'gold' And then, the next time the test runs, we get a parsed function, which we then add, which then always passes. So it fails only on first run. Probably because ethabi is not present on the machine.

We probably don't need this any longer since we can now fully parse the ABI in code without ethaabi.
This is now available through the [{PARSED}] display string token
Who cares.
completed by removing dependancy on ethabi.

Search for these words in relation to this issue:

BLOCK_CACHE
setStorageRoot
makeClass
makeClassCmd
jrush
src.GitHub
grabABI
getHomeFolder
classDir
options.classDir
out.Replace("[{DIR}]", options.classDir.Substitute(getHomeFolder(), "~/"));

This bug is fixed.
This is a more general problem that will be fixed when I incorporate a real JSON parser. The current parser works fine for Ethereum data (which is not anywhere recursive).
Eventually, I will replace the JSON code with a 'real' JSON parser. This will get fixed then. Closing this since it's not so slow that it matters.
No longer true. Closing.
Fixed. Bloom filters report at 0x if empty, 0x000....padded left with zeros to proper length otherwise.
Or better yet, use namespaces, which is what I think they are for.
